sect2.title: Export selected

row.entry: Each workflow ends in this panel: the export of your developed images. You can export either to a file on disk, or to various on-line storage places. You can also use Ctrl + e from within darkroom mode to export.

sect2.para:
All settings for this panel can be saved for later reuse. Press the
button to manage your presets.

sect4.title: target storage
sect4.para: Where to store your selected images. Different back-ends are implemented, including file on disk, a LaTeX book template, and various web albums. Depending on the selected target, you will be asked to give additional information, like filenames, or account name and password.

sect4.title: filename template
sect4.para: You can define filenames that darktable generates for export. Several variables can be used as placeholders:

row.entry: $(ROLL_NAME)
film roll of the RAW input image
$(FILE_FOLDER)
folder containing the RAW input image
$(FILE_NAME)
basename of the RAW input image
$(FILE_EXTENSION)
file extension of the RAW input image
$(SEQUENCE)
a file's number among the sequence of files for the export job
$(YEAR)
year at the date of export
$(MONTH)
month at the date of export
$(DAY)
day at the date of export
$(HOUR)
hour at the time of export
$(MINUTE)
minute at the time of export
$(SECOND)
second at the time of export
$(EXIF_YEAR)
year from the image's EXIF data, i.e., the year the photo was taken
$(EXIF_MONTH)
month from the image's EXIF data, i.e., the month the photo was taken
$(EXIF_DAY)
day from the image's EXIF data, i.e., the day the photo was taken
$(EXIF_HOUR)
hour from the image's EXIF data, i.e., the hour the photo was taken
$(EXIF_MINUTE)
minute from the image's EXIF data, i.e., the minute the photo was taken
$(EXIF_SECOND)
second from the image's EXIF data, i.e., the second the photo was taken
$(STARS)
the number for the image's star rating; so a rating of four stars will show as just 4
$(LABELS)
the image's color label; if there are multiple labels, these are separated by commas without spaces
$(PICTURES_FOLDER)
the desktop user account's default pictures folder
$(HOME)
the desktop user account's home folder
$(DESKTOP)
the desktop user account's desktop folder

sect4.title: output directory
sect4.para:
Pressing the
button opens a dialog to select a directory to contain the exported files.

sect4.title: overwrite
sect4.para: Enabling the overwrite checkbox allows darktable to overwrite existing images during export. If this option is not checked, in cases of naming conflict, darktable automatically selects a new unique file name (generally adding a suffix like _1 or _2 before the file extensions). The overwrite option gets reset after each export in order to protect you from accidental data loss.

sect4.title: file format
sect4.para: darktable can export to various file formats. For some of them you need to define the desired bit depth of the exported image. If you export to a JPEG file, you can define an output quality, which determines how lossy the JPEG compression algorithm will be. (PNG and TIFF are lossless image formats.) Higher values for bit depth or JPEG quality will lead to larger file sizes.

If the file format supports embedded metadata, like JPEG, JPEG2000 and TIFF, darktable will also try to store the history stack as XMP tags within the output file. This information can later be used to reconstruct your parameters and settings that have produced the exported image (see ).

para.emphasis: Caution: for various reasons, embedding XMP tags into output files may fail without notice, e.g., if certain size limits are exceeded. Users are therefore advised to not completely rely on this feature to save the history stack. To backup your data, make sure to save your input (RAW) file as well as all of darktable's XMP sidecar files.

sect4.para: If you don't want to distribute history stack data with your images, there are various tools to delete embedded XMP tags. As an example you can use the program exiftool with:

sect4.title: max size
sect4.para: Set the maximum width and height of the output images in pixels. Set both to a value of "0" to export the full image size. darktable currently can only do down-scaling, so the maximum output image size is defined by the source image.

para.emphasis: Caution: Some users accidentally enter low values, like 1 or 10, in these fields, causing darktable to produce tiny output files. You might think darktable's output is broken, but in fact it only generated what you asked for.

sect4.title: intent
sect4.para: This option lets you define the intent – i.e., the way darktable will deal with out-of-gamut colors. See for a more detailed description of the available options.

sect4.title: profile
sect4.para: This defines the output color profile. Select image settings if you want the settings in the output color profile (see ) of the individual images to take precedence.

sect4.title: style
sect4.para: This option lets you choose a style: a collection of history stack items, which darktable concatenates with the existing history stack to generate the output image. These history items are only added temporarily; the original history stack does not change. You can use this feature to add extra processing steps and parameters that you want to be applied to a particular batch of exported images. For example, you may define a style that adds a stronger level of sharpening, and apply it when you produce scaled-down JPEG files for the web. Learn more about styles in , and .

sect4.title: export
sect4.para: Pressing this button starts the export process for all selected images; the export will run in the background so you can continue work developing other images, if you wish. A bar at the bottom of the left side panel displays the export progress. Whenever a file is successfully exported, a notification message pops up for a few seconds. You may click on the pop-up to make it disappear sooner.
